13.text:
Welcome to the beautiful Lincoln Memorial.
The monument is built in honor of the 16th

19.text:
President of the United States; Abraham Lincoln.
While it is only one of several monuments

25.text:
built to honor an American president, many
regard this one as the very finest one. Partly

30.text:
because of the beauty of the monument, but
also because of the man it is built to honor.

38.text:
Before going into details about the monument
itself, I want to give you a brief summary

42.text:
of who Abraham Lincoln was.
Abraham Lincoln was born in 1809 on a small

50.text:
farm south of Hodgenville, Kentucky. He was
raised in a poor home, being the son of two

57.text:
uneducated farmers. Abraham himself however,
quickly developed an interest in studies.

63.text:
While his formal education consisted of about
18 months of schooling from unofficial teachers,

69.text:
he still mastered the Bible, William Shakespeare's
works, English history and American history.

76.text:
He was very much self educated, reading every
book he could get his hands on. He soon developed

83.text:
a plain writing and rhetorical style that
puzzled audiences. This brought him into politics

90.text:
at the age of 23, when he became a member
of the Whig party, and later elected to a

96.text:
term is the US House of Representatives in
1846. With his unorthodox rhetorical style

105.text:
he made both enemies and friends and left
the politics after one term and began working

111.text:
as a lawyer. He later returned to politics,
and this time got a much more central role,

118.text:
as he won the Republican Party nomination
in 1860 and was elected president the same

126.text:
year. Lincoln's hatred for slavery made the
already strained relation between the northern

131.text:
and southern states even more problematic.
The civil war broke out the very next year.

139.text:
Throughout the civil war, Lincoln was the
political leader for the Union and his leadership

144.text:
qualities helped to preserve the Unites States
to what it is today. Lincoln rallied public

150.text:
opinion through the powerful rhetoric of his
messages and speeches. His "Gettysburg Address",

157.text:
the speech he gave a few months after the
Union victory at Gettysburg, is a prime example

163.text:
and one of the most quoted speeches in US
history. Lincoln is however most known for

170.text:
issuing his Emancipation Proclamation and
his contribution in passing the Thirteenth

175.text:
Amendment which permanently abolished slavery
in the US. In 1865, shortly after the war

184.text:
was won, Lincoln was assassinated while watching
a theatre act. This made him a martyr for

191.text:
the ideal of national unity and he's today
one of the most famous and highly ranked of

197.text:
all US presidents.
The first planning of constructing a memorial

203.text:
to Lincoln started in two years after his
assassination. However, the site for the memorial

210.text:
was not chosen until 1902. Congress formally
authorized the memorial in 1911 and the first

217.text:
stone was put into place three years later
on Lincoln's birthday, February 12. The monument

224.text:
was dedicated in 1922, with Lincolns then
only surviving child, Robert Todd Lincoln,

231.text:
attending the ceremony.
The building you are looking at is made out

235.text:
of Indiana limestone and Yule marble, which
gives the memorial its shining white color.

242.text:
The building is heavily inspired by the ancient
Greek Temple of Zeus. This is not only evident

249.text:
because it is surrounded by massive columns,
but also because it is centered around a large

254.text:
statue of a man sitting on a throne. In the
Temple of Zeus it was Zeus sitting on the

261.text:
throne; in this case it's Abraham Lincoln.
The 36 columns are interpreted as representing

269.text:
the 25 U.S. states at the time of Lincoln's
death, as well as the 11 Confederate states.

276.text:
If you take a look above the columns, you
will the see name of the states inscribed

281.text:
in the order that each state joined the Union
along with the year of their joining in Roman

286.text:
numerals. The names of the remaining 22 states
that had joined the Union when the memorial

293.text:
was completed are carved on the exterior attic
walls in the same manner, even though it can

299.text:
be hard to see from the ground. A plaque in
front of the monument also honors the admission

306.text:
of Alaska and Hawaii in 1959.
While the outside itself is very beautiful,

314.text:
the focus of the memorial is Daniel Chester
French's sculpture of Lincoln, seated on a

321.text:
throne, stoically looking east over the reflecting
pool towards the Washington Monument. The

327.text:
statue was carved from 28 blocks f white Georgia
marble and stands six meters high and six

335.text:
meters wide. Behind the statue on the wall,
you can read the phrase:

343.text:
IN THIS TEMPLE
AS IN THE HEARTS OF THE PEOPLE

346.text:
FOR WHOM HE SAVED THE UNION
THE MEMORY OF ABRAHAM LINCOLN

351.text:
IS ENSHRINED FOREVER
You can also find some of Lincoln's speeches

357.text:
inscribed on the walls inside the memorial.
On the south side you can find his famous

363.text:
speech at Gettysburg and on the other side
his second inaugural speech.

369.text:
This site itself has also been the place for
several famous speeches. The most famous one

375.text:
came in 1963, during one of the greatest political
rallies in US history; the March on Washington

383.text:
for Jobs and Freedom which gathered more than
250.000 people in the area surrounding the

389.text:
memorial. They came to hear Martin Luther
King, Jr. deliver his memorable speech, "I

395.text:
Have a Dream," before the memorial honoring
the president who had issued the Emancipation

401.text:
Proclamation 100 years earlier. If you take
a look at the steps just in front of the building,

408.text:
you will see an inscription in the ground,
marking where King stood when he held his

414.text:
speech.
The Lincoln memorial is today a very popular

417.text:
place for visitors, not only typical tourists,
but also many schools take field trips to

423.text:
the memorial in educational purpose. In total,
an estimate of more than 3.5 million people
